Issues.Title: Convert VB ArrayList usage to List<T>
Issues.Body:
Work related to #8140

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8141)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Convert VB ArrayList usage to List<T>" (#8141)

Issues.Title: Convert `ArrayList` usage to `List<T>` where possible
Issues.Body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

Winforms uses `Arraylist` extensively.

### Describe the solution you'd like and alternatives you've considered

Convert `Arraylist` usage to `List<T>` to reduce boxing and improve memory utilization.

### Will this feature affect UI controls?

N/A

Related: #2644
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Convert `ArrayList` usage to `List<T>` where possible" (#8140)

Issues.Title: Update backport action environment to Node 16
Issues.Body:
### Problem
<!-- Add the issue number if exists. Describe the problem otherwise. -->
🚨 Node 12 has an end of life on April 30, 2022.

The GitHub Actions workflow gives the following warning while running the action:

> Node.js 12 actions are deprecated. For more information see: github.blog/changelog/2022-09-22-github-actions-all-actions-will-begin-running-on-node16-instead-of-node12.

Similar dep: https://github.com/dotnet/templating/pull/5576

### Solution
<!-- Describe the solution. -->
This PR updates the default runtime to [node16](https://github.blog/changelog/2021-12-10-github-actions-github-hosted-runners-now-run-node-js-16-by-default/) rather then node12. 

This is supported on all Actions Runners v2.285.0 or later.

Signed-off-by: Enes <ahmedenesturan@gmail.com>

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8135)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Update backport action environment to Node 16" (#8135)

Issues.Title: Introduce and use TraceVerbose extension method
Issues.Body:
## Proposed changes

- Introduce and use TraceVerbose extension method
- Addresses https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8072#discussion_r1009826425
- Since this involves many changes, we can use the method in System.Windows.Forms.Design in a separate PR.
- We can also introduce TraceInfo and other extension methods in a separate PR.

Issues.Title: Clean up docs/list-of-diagnostics.md
Issues.Body:
Fixed unavailable links and replaced with working ones. Previous links were based on the format for dotnet/runtime obsoletions from  https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/project/list-of-diagnostics.md, but for WinForms these pages were added to .NET Desktop docs instead of general .NET docs.

Issues.Title: FolderBrowserDialog throws AccessViolationException and crashes when creating a new folder in a USB drive with no space available
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

6.0.10

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

The issue happens when trying to create a new folder in a USB flash drive with no space available through FolderBrowserDialog or SaveFileDialog.

USB Device:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14222884/200080315-a9984053-3590-4a3b-8109-dc94482defe4.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14222884/200082157-6cd44b7d-174c-4f9d-899c-96d53c1650ed.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14222884/200082951-dbcc1ec1-cd78-45bd-bd39-062711eb27d8.png)


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14222884/200079421-73a8047a-e050-4443-ada7-fc942a1c9479.png)

The reference screenshots for this test show a Windows install flash drive with a NTFS partition, but it also happened in previous tests with FAT flash drives.

This issue was originally discovered in a .NET Framework 4.8 application but seems to occur in the .NET 6 implementation as well.

I also tried reproducing the issue in multiple machines with different devices, still persists.

Using a virtual disk (simulating a device with no space available) had the expected behaviour (another dialog shows up notifying the user there's no space available and suggesting them to clean up the device).

Could this be a shell problem? During these tests I figured the issue also seems to happen with explorer.exe itself, I can consistently crash it by trying to create a folder under the same conditions described.

### Steps to reproduce

* Open a FolderBrowserDialog (or SaveFileDialog) with the ShowDialog() method
* Select a full USB device (0 bytes available)
* Create a new folder from within the dialog, either through the context menu option or the New Folder button, in said device
    - Creating the folder with the top left "New Folder" button causes the AccessViolationException to be thrown
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14222884/200083410-d574f2e8-209b-43cb-bfd4-a49ea2d20a45.png)
    - Creating the folder with the context menu option causes the application to crash silently with no exceptions, even when "EnableUnmanagedDebugging" is set to true (this seems to show more information in the .NET Framework 4.8 version)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "FolderBrowserDialog throws AccessViolationException and crashes when creating a new folder in a USB drive with no space available" (#8116)
